title.narrative: Bridging the Gaps: Georgian Network of People who Use Drugs

description.narrative: BtG aims to facilitate community development by: 1. Building of national PWUD network; Facilitating community development on advocacy. 2. Advocating for the continuous strengthening of services and upholding human rights for young people who use drugs. 5. Implementing an efficient and high-quality Needle and Syringe Programme; 6. Foster global and in-country processes and partnerships that reinforce results. 7. Improving partnerships in-country with other NGOs, government, and organisations that can assist in (data) management systems.

Georgia is one of the countries with the harshest drug policies in the Eastern European and Central Asian region. In the same time, the country is host of strong, progressive grass-root movements which advocate for social change, civil rights and the end of the war on drugs. In a geopolitical landscape dominated by the Russian Federation, Georgia took steps which go against the regional trend, for instance in what concerns evidence-based harm reduction interventions which are still controversial in neighbouring countries. One example is opiate assisted therapy, which is now part of the national treatment system. Georgia endorses harm reduction interventions. While maintaining a hard line on drugs, Georgia has decriminalised the possession of cannabis.

comment.narrative: Bridging the Gaps uses two age groups since 2017 reporting onwards: 24 and under, and 25 and above, as agreed with MOFA. For the sex work project, the youngest age group will be 18-24 years.

Focus-group discussion took place in four big cities of Georgia, representing four regions of the country. The age gap of the participants resonance between 18-30 years. Minimum of 8 and maximum of 10 respondents were included during the discussions. The average time of the focus-groups was an hour and a half. In the four cities (Tbilisi, Batumi, Kutaisi, Zugdidi), which were covered by the research, various trends of drug-using were revealed, according to drugs, receiving sources and dosages.
